title: Beyond the Code: How IT Clubs Train Tech Leaders
body: When most people think of IT clubs, they imagine students huddled around laptops debugging code. ...
summary: IT clubs don't just create better coders—they develop leadership, communication, and strategic thinking for real-world tech environments.
author: Hoàng Lê Bách

title: Design Thinking for Developers: Why It Matters
body: Code without context is just syntax. Today’s software engineers need to understand user needs as deeply as system architecture. Enter design thinking—a methodology that places empathy and user experience at the core of problem-solving. ...
summary: Design thinking bridges the gap between engineering and real-world problem-solving, empowering devs to build with purpose.
author: Trần Anh Minh

title: Firebase Best Practices: Real-World Lessons from Student Projects
body: Working with Firebase seems easy—until your Firestore costs spike and your reads explode. Student-led projects often start simple but can become complex fast. Here’s what they’ve learned the hard way, and how you can avoid common pitfalls. ...
summary: Student-led Firebase projects reveal the dos and don’ts of scalable app architecture, with real deployment insights.
author: Nguyễn Thị Mai

title: From Hackathon to Production: What It Really Takes
body: A weekend prototype can feel like magic. But taking it to production? That’s a different beast. Student teams often face the realities of tech debt, refactoring, CI/CD, and feature creep. This post walks through that messy, vital transition. ...
summary: Hackathons build speed—but polishing a project for real users teaches resilience, architecture, and delivery.
author: Phạm Văn Khoa

title: The Silent Skills: Communication in Code Reviews
body: We focus so much on writing good code, but what about talking about it? Code reviews are where developers learn to express intent, offer critique, and negotiate decisions. For students, mastering this space can make or break a team project. ...
summary: Code reviews aren't just about bugs—they're about empathy, clarity, and mutual respect.
author: Lê Vũ Long
